intro: Comolia hirtella, commonly known as the hairy comolia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves, which give it its common name. It produces showy, five-petaled flowers that are typically pink or purple in color. Comolia hirtella thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky soils and open woodlands.
